content.question: The position of an object moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis is given by the equation <math alttext="x of t equals, t squared minus 6 t, plus 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, where <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is in meters and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is time in seconds. Does the object’s direction of motion change and what reasoning supports that claim?

choices.label: No because <math alttext="x is greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math> at any given time.
No because the acceleration is constant and nonzero.
Yes because the object is located at the origin at <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> s</mtext></math>.
Yes because the velocity of the object changes sign at <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> s</mtext></math>.

content.answer: Yes because the velocity of the object changes sign at <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> s</mtext></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
